creator: National Endowment for the Humanities Collaborative Research Grant
subject: Baptisms
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume contains baptisms of free individuals from the now-defunct Freguesia of Santo Antônio de Sá. A number of the baptisms were performed in the Capela (later, Igreja) de São José da Boa Morte. Although there is a note from the priest who inaugurated the volume indicating that the volume will be used to record the baptisms of white individuals, the baptisms of several free people of color were also recorded in the volume. On the cover of the volume is written 1762-9, indicating that many pages are probably missing. The surviving entries date from 28 March 1762 through 15 February 1764.  Fair condition

volumes.title: Book 8 of Slave, Free, and Freed Baptisms, 1860 - 1872
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Baptisms
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume records baptisms of enslaved, freed (forro), and free individuals that took place between 27 Dec 1860 and 03 Nov 1872 in the Church of Nossa Senhora da Assunção de Cabo Frio, RJ. The opening and closing charters were signed by Francisco Antonio de Soares on 27 Sep 1860. The entries were signed by Pastor José Francisco Marques. Some baptisms from previous years (1833, 1847, 1841), recorded by order of the vicar of the ecclesiastical jurisdication, appear. Some entries refer to African origins; others note "alforrias de pia"--manumissions at the baptismal font. There are baptisms of children abandoned at the charity house (expostos da casa de caridade); some entries refer to natives of the indigenous community, São Pedro da Aldeia.

Only the opening charter, signed by Vicar Manoel d'Almeida Barreto on 30 Jun 1799, has survived. The volume refers to slaves of the Angolan and English "nation," as well as to slaves belonging to Father João Manoel Porto. The baptism of a child of Lieutenant Henriques Martins de Oliveira is recorded in this volume. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Manoel d'Almeida, Antonio Pereira Ribeiro, Matheus Vicente Sabino, Miguel Lopes de Castro, and Joseph Correa Sá Coelho.

volumes.title: Book 3 of Slave, Freed, and Free Marriages, 1849-1867
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Marriages
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume contains marriage records of enslaved, freed (forro), and free people registered in the Church of Nossa Senhora da Assunção de Cabo Frio, RJ between 29 Apr 1849 and 05 Apr 1867. It does not have an opening or closing charter. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Vicar José Francisco Ferraz Durão; Coadjutor Ignácio Felizardo Fortes; and parish priest (pároco) José Francisco Marques. Among others, the volume documents marriages between free white people and freed people of color (pardos forros); a marriage between an indigenous groom and an African-descended bride (fl.62v); a marriage between an indigenous groom and a white bride (fl 72f); marriages between free whites and freed people of color; and the marriages of Portuguese and French people. Some of the freed people have parents who remain enslaved, some of them belonging to Captain Manoel Furtado de Mendonça. Among enslaved brides and grooms appear a number of slaves belonging to Father Joaquim Gonçalves Porto, a major slaveholder. African ethnonyms/"nations" mentioned: Benguela and Rebolo. Among others, the volume documents the marriages of the following elites: Doctor José Vieira de Almeida, Bacharel Domingos de Oliveira Maria, Doctor Albino da Silva Maia (whose wedding was celebrated in the oratory of the plantation (fazenda) of Captain Antonio Garcia da Roza Terra in Porto do Carro), Doctor Carlos Augusto Ferraz de Abreu, and a mixed-race son of Lieutenant Colonel  Antonio José de Souza, who was a native of the Vila da Barra de São João. Interestingly, formerly enslaved brides and grooms and/or slaves are frequently referred to as "innocents" (inocentes), a term usually reserved for children in baptismal and burial records.

coverage.institution: Igreja de Nossa Senhora da Assunção

format: The volume is comprised of 199 numbered, sequential folios in good condition that have come loose from the binding. The cover is intact. Some of the folios are difficult to read due to ink damage. Dimensions: 33cm x 23cm.

volumes.description: The volume records marriages of enslaved, freed (forro), free, and indigenous people registered in the Church of Nossa Senhora da Assunção de Cabo Frio, RJ between 11 Aug 1879 and 06 Aug 1925. Claudio da Costa Guimarães signed the opening and closing charters and initialed each folio in the volume. Among others, the volume records marraiges of Portuguese individuals; between enslaved and freed people; freed people with enslaved parents. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Parish priest José Francisco (Fran.co) Marques, Vicar Alexandre (?), Vicar Cipriano Bernardt, Vicar Antonio Chiromonse, Diogo Freitas O. F. M., Canon Vicar José Joaquim de Britto, Vicar Vicente Teneza Gallach, Vicar Joaquim Dias da Costa, Vicar Paulo Itamile, and Father José Duarte Nunes.

coverage.institution: Igreja de Nossa Senhora da Assunção

format: The volume is comprised of 196 numbered folios in good condition with a cover; a few folios are torn and/or show signs of insect and ink damage. Dimensions:  34cm X 23cm.

volumes.title: Book 4 of Freed, Free, and Indian Marriages, 1867-1879
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Marriages
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume contains marriage records of freed (forro), free, and indigenous people registered in the Church of Nossa Senhora da Assunção de Cabo Frio, RJ between 09 Sep 1867 and 27 Sep 1879. Juiz Provedor Constantino José Gonçalves signed the opening and closing charters on 31 Mar 1867; parish priest  José Francisco Marques signed all entries. Marriages recorded in this volume were celebrated in São Pedro da Aldeia, Sacra Família da Barra de São João, the chapel of  Nossa Senhora dos Remédios de Arraial, the Chapel of Santo Ignacio da Fazenda de Campos Novos, the Chapel of Santa Anna da Armação de Búzioa, S. Vicente de Paulo and S. Sebastião de Araruama, and various oratories on area agricultural properties. The social status (freed, free, Indian, white) and color of the bride and groom appear in the margin. The volume also records marriages of individuals abandoned in the House of Charity (Expostos da Casa de Caridade) and the children of slaves.

coverage.institution: Igreja de Nossa Senhora da Assunção

format: The volume is comprised of 98 numbered folios in good condition overall and a cover. Some of the folios have holes in them. Dimensions: 40.5cm X 27cm.

volumes.title: Book 10 of Burials, 1871 - 1887
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Burials
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume records burials of children born to enslaved women after the passage of Lei  2.040/1871 (the "Free Womb" Law) registered in the Church of Nossa Senhora da Assunção de Cabo Frio, in Cabo Frio, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. A transcription of Lei 2.040, which declared the children of enslaved women free, appears on the first page of the volume. The opening and closing charters were signed by  Antonio André Lins (of the secretary of the Provincial Government) and dated  01 May 1872. Entries date from 31 Oct 1871 to 27 Dec 1887. José Francisco Marques signed the entries. Slaves belonging to the Baron of Capanema (Barão de Capanema) and burials in the region of Sacra Familia appear.

coverage.institution: Igreja de Nossa Senhora da Assunção

format: The volume is well conserved and consists of 171 numbered folios and a cover; folios 41v through 171 are blank. Dimensions:  33 cm x 23.5 cm.

The opening charter is dated 27 Oct 1768 and was signed by  José da Cruz Domingos; there is no closing charter. The volume has some marriage records from the year 1786. Marriages date from 1728-12-28 to 1743-01-21.

volumes.description:
"Serve este livro para se escreverem os assentos dos Batizados da Capela Curada de Nossa Senhora da Ajuda de Guapimirim, e também para os inventários das coizas da fábrica da Capela que começa da folha 120. Freguesia de Nossa Senhora da Ajuda 17 de outubro de 1727. Lourenço de Valadares Vieira."
"Por não achar nos livros dessa Igreja assentos dos defuntos e serem estes assentos tam necessários me deliberey a lançallos neste livro, os quais dão principio a folhos cento e continuarão dali para adiante os Parrochos q (ilegível)...P[adre] Joseph da Cruz"

The entries were signed by the following priests: Antonio Ribeiro Rangel; Vicar José Simões da Motta; Vicar José Teixeira; Vicar Luiz Caetano Guerreyro de Souza. Freed (forro) and enslaved individuals appear as witnesses in the registers; the following African ethnonyms (nações) are mentioned: Benguella (Benguela), Mina, and Guiné (Guinea). The volume records numerous marriages transacted by slaves belonging to one Francisco Ribeiro Guerra.

volumes.title: Book 6 of Freed and Free Burials, 1750-1799
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Burials
Brazil
volumes.description: This volume records the burials of freed (forro) and free individuals registered in the Church of Santo Antônio de Sá, Itaboraí-RJ, as well as some testaments that mention enslaved individuals (the donation of enslaved individuals; their manumission; and estimates of their value). Entries date from 18 Mar 1750 through 22 Aug 1799 and were signed by the following clergy: Vicar José Pereira Távora; Francisco Ferreira de Azevedo; and Coadjutor Antonio Pereira Jorge de Sevilha. It has no opening or closing charters. The volume includes some burials of Portuguese individuals as well as the testaments of Capitão Mor Francisco Antonio Leão and Father Manoel da Costa Moreira. One unidentified testament refers to a request for honors (mercê) from D. Maria I of Portugal.  African "nations"/ethnonyms mentioned: Guiné (Guinea), Angola, Benguela, Mina, and Camundongo.

volumes.title: Book 11 of Free Burials, 1842-1862
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Burials
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume consists of burial records of free individuals registered in the Church of Santo Antônio de Sá, Itaboraí-RJ, and includes testaments that refer to land and slaves (and, in some cases, the manumission of enslaved individuals the "donation" of enslaved individuals, and evaluations of their monetary value). Entries date from 10 Apr 1842 through 12 Feb 1862. The opening and closing charters were signed by interim Municipal Judge Luis Cardim da Silva, who also initialed the folios. The volume also includes some burial records of Portuguese individuals. African "nations"/ethnonyms mentioned: Congo. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Vicar Francisco (Fran.co) Antonio (An.to) Soares de Medeiros (Med.os); Vicar Virtulino Bezerra Cavalcanti; Vicar Aniceto Martins de Pinhero; Vicar Tito Per.a de Carv.o; Coadjutor Aniceto Martins de Bilbao; and Coadjutor Jose Narciro Pereira.

Entries date from 08 Oct 1871 to 10 Apr 1888. There is no opening charter; the volume was viewed and closed by D. Francisco, Bishop of Petrópolis, on 28 May 1898. Some of the baptisms took place in a satellite parish, the chapel of Santo Antonio. The following clergy signed the entries: Manoel Florentino Cassiano Campos and Joaquim de Azevedo Castro.

volumes.title: Book 3 of Free and Freed Burials, 1860-1880
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Burials
Brazil
volumes.description: This volume contains burial records of freed (forro) and free indivduals registered in the Church of Nossa Senhora da Conceição de Porto das Caixas, Itaboraí-RJ.The entries date from 31 Jan 1860 through 26 Jan 1880. Of the opening and closing charters, only the opening charter has urvived and was signed by Vicar Joaquim Freire de Azevedo Coutinho on 17 Jan 1892 in Porto das Caixas. Vicar Manoel Florentino Cassiano de Campos and Vicar Joaquim Freire de Azevedo Coutinho signed the burial records. The entries include the burials of children (inocentes); abandoned children (expostos); children born to enslaved mothers after the passage of the "Free Womb Law" (Lei do Ventre Livre"-- Lei 2040 of 28 Sept 1871); as well as of Portuguese, French, Spanish, and Swiss individuals. African "nations"/ethnonyms mentioned: Angola, Mina, and Moçambique (Mozambique). In some instances, the cause of death was recorded.

coverage.institution: Nossa Senhora da Conceição de Porto das Caixas

creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Baptisms
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume records baptisms of enslaved and free individuals registered in the Church of Nossa Senhora do Desterro de Itambi, Itaboraí, Rio de Janeiro. Entries date from 17 Feb 1703 through 02 Apr 1741. The opening charter was signed by one Costa on 13 Dec 1701, while the closing charter was signed by Gonçalo de Moura on 13 Aug 1733. The volume records baptisms of abandoned children (expostos) that occurred in the house of Father Zephyrino de Andrade Costa as well as baptisms of enslaved adults. It refers to slaves of Captain Francisco de Oliveira (?) and Captain Antonio Pereyra de Araujo. African ethnonyms mentioned: Guiné (Guinea), Mina. The volume notes pastoral visits that took place on 22 Oct 1729, 14 Oct 1733, 28 Jan 1337, and 28 Jan 1737. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Father Joaquim (?) da Fonseca Rangel, Joaquim Lopes Sodré, Father Custódio Cardoso Cortês, Father Severino de Andrade Costa, and Father Manoel (M.el) Beas.

volumes.title: Book 1 of Slave Baptisms and Burials, 1719-1767
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Baptisms
Brazil
volumes.description: This volume contains burial and baptismal records of enslaved individuals registered in the church of Nossa Senhora do Desterro de Itambi, Itaboraí, Rio de Janeiro. Entries date from 23 Sept 1719 through 27 Dec 1767. Burial records date from 1719-1742, while baptismal records date from 1765-1767. There is no opening charter; the closing charter was signed by  Dr. Henrique Moreira Carvalho on 07 Jan 1740. There are records of slaves enterred in the sepulchre of the house of the Brotherhood of the Blacks of the Rosary (Irmandade do Rosário dos Pretos). This volume has records of slaves owned by Teniente Euzebio Alfonso Homem and Captain André da Cunha de Mattoz. Ethnonyms and "nations" mentioned: Guiné (Guinea), Mina, Angola, Benguela, Moçambique (Mozambique). The entries were signed by Vicar Joaquim Nunes Cabral, Zephyrino de Andrade Costa, José Mendes, Custódio Cardozo Cortês, and Florêncio (?) da Roza.

volumes.description: The volume contains burial records of freed (forro) and free individuals registered in the Church of São João Batista, Itaboraí-RJ, between 05 Nov 1827 and 29 Nov 1836. J. Caetano Ferreira Aguiar signed the opening charter on 17 Jan 1827, while Father Jose Gregorio de Carvalho signed the closing charter on 06 Nov 1828 and initialed each folio in the volume. The volume records, among others, the burials of children (inocentes), abandoned individuals, Captain Alexandre Alves de Azevedo, Lieutenant Manoel Fidelis Roiz de Figueiredo, Ensign Jose Roiz da Costa, Brigadier Jacinto de Mello Palhares, Ensign Jose Joaquim Quintanilha, Father Jose Pinto da Silva Borges, Major João Alvares de Azevedo, Ensign Joze Luiz Vieira dos Santos, Captain Joze Maurício de Abreu Rangel, Colonel Bernardino Joze Antunes, Ensign Francisco Joze da Costa Guimarães, Captain Manoel Joaquim de Mendonça, Father Luiz Antonio Ferreira Menezes Drumond, Ensign Claudio Nunes da Roza, Lieutenant Colonel Antonio Rodrigues de Figueiredo, Ensign Antonio Joaquim de Marins Coutinho, Captain João Manuel de Azeredo Coutinho, Major João Maria de Campos, Ensign João Freire de Azevedo Coutinho, Lieutenant Colonel Luis Manoel Pereira, Reverend João Gonçalves de Carvalho, and Reverend Francisco da Costa Cardozo. In addition to burials, the volume also includes some testaments that refer to enslaved people and, in some cases, provide for their manumission after the death of their owner. T

volumes.title: Book 5 of Freed and Free Burials, 1860-1871
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Burials
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume contains burials of freed (forro) and free individuals registered in the Church of  São João Batista, Itaboraí-RJ, between 23 Oct 1860 and 13 Dec 1871. Municipal Judge and of Chapels Cyrillo Nunes Fagos (?) signed the opening and closing charters in Itaboraí on 13 Aug 1861 and initialed the folios of the volume. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Vicar Joaquim (?) Marianno de Castro Araujo and Coadjutor Manoel Joaquim Dias. Among others, the volume records the burials of children (inocentes), individuals abandoned in the Santa Casa de Misericórdia (some with an identification number); Portuguese, Spanish, and Italian indivdiuals; Major Cosme Botelho de Velasco Coutinho. The cause of death was usually recorded. African ethnonyms/"nations": Mina and Benguela (Benguella). The burial records of freed people include two entries concerning ex-slaves of the Baron of Itapacorá and one entry concerning a "freed black woman" ("preta liberta") who was interred in the Chapel of Lieutenant Colonel Ignacio Balthasar. There is a record of an enslaved woman (fl 101f) that was signed later without effect, as can be seen on folio 111(f).  The volume also documents the pastoral visit of Francisco, Bishop of Niterói, on 09 Jul 1894.

coverage.institution: São João Batista de Itaboraí

volumes.title: Book 7 of Freed and Free Burials, 1871-1885
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Burials
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume records burials of freed (forro) and free individuals registered in the Church of  São João Batista, Itaboraí-RJ, between 15 Dec 1871 and 08 Mar 1885. Municipal Judge Jeronimo (?) D'Almeida signed the opening and closing charters on 24 Jan 1872. Coadjutor Bernardo Cardoso de Araujo and Vicar Joaquim Mariano de Castro Araujo signed each entry. Some of the entries note the cause of death, including fever, anemia, inflammation of the liver, hydropsy, whooping cough, childbirth, opulação, pneumonia, inflammation,  Em alguns registros constam "Causa Mortis", dentre elas:  pneumonia, inflamação, anemia, febre, and blood fatigue ('caimbra de sangue'.) Some of the entries note the color of the cloth used to wrap the deceased. Among others, the volume records the burials of individuals abandoned in the Santa Casa de Misericórdia and their number. The volume also documents a pastoral visit realized by Francisco, Bishop of Nictheroy, on 12 Jul 1894. Burials took place in the catacombs "of the factory," "of the town hall," and the Coutinho Family Cemetery (cemitério dos Coutinho).

volumes.title: Book 14 of Baptisms, 1871 - 1880
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Baptisms
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume records baptisms of children born to enslaved mothers after the passage of the Free Womb Law, registered in the Church of Nossa Senhora do Amparo de Maricá, Maricá-RJ. Entries date from 25 Oct 1871 to 4 Jan 1880. There are no opening or closing charters. There are registers of children born to enslaved mothers after the passage of the Free Womb Law as well as of free white people. Both parents are freed (forro) in some of the registers. Entries were signed by the following clergy:  Vicar Sebastião de Azevedo Araújo  e Gama and Coadjutor Francisco Leite de Almeida Magalhães.

volumes.title: Book 7 of Slave, Freed, and Free Baptisms, 1800 - 1816
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Baptisms
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume records baptisms of enslaved and free people registered in the Church of Nossa Senhora do Amparo de Maricá, Maricá-RJ. Entries date from 10 May 1800 to 29 Oct 1816. There are no opening or closing charters. There are records of manumissions at the baptismal font (alforrias de pia); of abandoned children (expostos); baptisms of children born to an enslaved father and freed (forro) mother; records of the donation of recently-baptized slaves; and records of slaves being freed. The entries also note the locations of the parents' baptisms. The volume notes that some of the records originated in Itaboraí and were given for transcription in the volume. There is a record of a parochial visit on 25 May 1803. The following clergy signed the entries: Coadjutor Antonio Valentino, Joze Ferreira dos Santos, and Vicar Vicente Ferreira.

volumes.title: Book 9 of Slave Burials, 1872 - 1875
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Burials
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume records burials of children born to enslaved mothers after the passage of Law 2.040 of 1871, the "Free Womb Law," registered in the Church of Nossa Senhora do Amparo de Maricá, Maricá-RJ. Entries date from 06 Nov 1871 to 15 May 1875.The opening charter was signed by the "Superior Official of the Secretary of the Government of the Province of  Rio de Janeiro," Antonio André Lins, on 01 May 1872. Sebastião de Azevedo Araujo e Gama signed the entries. The declaration "came as a guide of the inspector" ("veio como guia do inspector") frequently appears. In some entries, the cause of death--frequently, "fevers"--appears. There is a burial record of a child of a slave belonging to one Father Manoel Joaquim de Azevedo Farias. On folio 16, an enslaved woman "should go to the square to pay debts to the fazenda" ("deve ir a praça para pagamento de dívidas da fazenda").

volumes.title: Book 3 of Freed and Free Burials, 1840 - 1845
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Burials
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume records burials of freed and free people registered in the Church of Nossa Senhora do Amparo de Maricá, Maricá-RJ, dating from 20 Sep 1840 to 12 May 1845. There are no opening or closing charters. The following clergy signed the entries: Vicar José Faustino Gomes da Santana, coadjutor; and Commissioned Vicar José Antonio Pacheco. There are burial records of Ensign (Alferes) Antonio Ribeiro; Captain Boaventura Ferreira Maciel, surgeon Antonio José Pereira; and Major José Ferreira Gomes, among others. A few burials of enslaved individuals were also recorded in the volume; following their transcription, "They are not valid because the book is incompetent" ("Não vale por ser em livro incompetente") is written. African ethnonyms mentioned: Congo. The cause of death is recorded in many cases, as is the material condition of the decedent (e.g. "poor"). There are some burial records of children abandoned at the Santa Casa de Misericórdia.

volumes.title: Book 5 of Slave, Freed, and Free Baptisms and Marriages, 1789-1868
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Baptisms
Brazil
volumes.description: This volume contains baptismal and marriage records of enslaved, freed (forro), and free people registered in the Church of São João Batista (Baptista) de Niterói-RJ. Baptismal entries date from 28 May 1789 through 01 Dec 1831, while the marriage records date from 05 Apr 1818 to 01 Aug 1868. The opening and closing charters refer only to the baptismal records. The opening charter appears on folio 33, signed 25 May 1789, but the signature is illegible. The closing charter was isgned on 28 May 1789 by Father  João Luis Vellozo. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Vicar José Joaquim de Avila, vigário colado Thomaz de Aquino, coadjutor Francisco Manoel d'Almeida Guimarães,  vigário Antonio de Mello Muniz Maia, coadjutor João Rebello Mello de Abreo, José Justo Valente. African ethnonyms and "nations: mentioned: Angola, Benguela, Cabinda, Cassange, Congo, Mina, and Moçambique (Mozambique). Due to condition issues, it was not possible to photograph the following folios: 18v-20v; 59v- 63.

coverage.institution: Catedral de São João Batista de Niterói

volumes.title: Book 2 of Slave and Free Baptisms, Marriages, and Burials, 1682-1701
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Baptisms
Brazil
volumes.description: This volume contains baptismal, marriage, and burial records of enslaved and free people registered in the Church of São João Batista (Baptista) de Niterói and covers the period from 28 Oct 1682 to 18 Jul 1701. There are no opening or closing charters. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Lourenço Carneiro de Araujo; Father João Alvares Maciel; Father Miguel Luis Freire; Father João Rangel de Macedo. The volume records three pastoral visits: two signed by Manoel da Costa Cordeyros (the first on 17 Sep 1691 and the second on 03 Nov 1701. The third was signed by João (?) Carvalho on 10 Sep 1688. The volume is divided into sections for "whites" and "blacks" (pretos), with "White Baptisms" recorded on fls. 1-34, "Black Baptisms" on fls. 66-104v; "White Marriages" fls. 105-113v; "Black Marriages" 127-132v. "Free Burials" comprise the remainder of the volume. A number of individuals are described as "gentios de Guiné."

coverage.institution: Catedral de São João Batista de Niterói

volumes.title: Book 21 of Free Baptisms, 1882-1884
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Baptisms
Brazil
volumes.description: This volume contains baptismal records of free people and children born to freed and enslaved people after the passage of Law 2040/1871, the "Free Womb" Law, and registered in the Church of  São João Batista (Baptista) de Niterói (Nictheroy). Entries date from 04 May 1882 through 21 Mar 1884. The opening charter was signed in Rio de Janeiro on 01 May 1882 by an individual with an illegible name; the closing charter was also signed in Rio de Janeiro on the same date by the  vigário cônego Antonio da Irmandade da Conceição. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Vicar Manoel Correia de Figueira, vigário cônego Luis Raymundo da Silva Britto e vigário cônego João Aureliano Correia dos Santos. Throughout the book, references to kinship and godparentage links between doctors, coronals, lieutenants, captains, and commanders are mentioned. Among the children born to enslaved mothers after the passage of the Free Womb Law are enslaved women belonging to: Doutor Luis Antonio de Miranda Freitas; Doutor Jeronimo Maximo Nogueira  (?); Barão do Rio Bonito; Doutor José de Sá Carvalho; Comendador Joaquim José Rodrigues Guimarães; Doutor José Martins Breha (?); Comendador Joaquim José de Souza Breves; Conselheiro Doutor Custodio Marcelino de Magalhães; Comendador Clemete José de Gois Vianna; Senador Filipe Franco de Sá (Senador representing Maranhão, acting between 1882 and 1889. In addition to serving as senator, he was Minister of Foreign Relations of Brazil in 1882, Minister of War in 1884, and Minister of Imperial Business (Ministro dos Negócios do Imperío) in 1884); Capitão Ingéro Elias Guimarães; Coronel Carlos de Sá Carvalho, and Doutor Francisco Carneiro de Campos.

coverage.institution: Catedral de São João Batista de Niterói

format: The volume consists of 99 numbered, sequential, bound folios. Dimensions: 45cmx28.5cm.

Entries date from 20 Mar 1884 to 20 Mar 1886. The opeing charter was signed by Canon Luis Raymundo da Silva Brito, General Vicar, on 16 Feb 1884. The closing charter was signed by  Vigário Conego João Aureliano Couveia dos Santos. The volume includes baptisms of children born to Portuguese parents as well as adults, as well as a record of a pastoral visit conducted on 06 Dec 1884 by Pedro, Bishop of  São Sebastião do Rio de Janeiro. Entries date from 20 Mar 1886 through 13 Mar 1887. The opening charter was signed by General Vicar Monsignor Brito, while the closing charter was signed on the same date by the Vicar of Niterói, Canon João Aureliano Correia dos Santos. All of the entires were signed by Canon João Aureliano Correia dos Santos. There are a number of references to enslaved mothers belonging to one Captain Dario Justo de Souza Mello. On folio 24, the owner of the child of the slave as folhas 24 a dona da da filha de escrava abdica dos Direitos que a Lei lhe concede pela liberdade da ingênua. There are a number of references to "creole" ("crioula"; American-born) women.

volumes.title: Book 1 of Slave, Freed, and Free Marriages, 1754-1795
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Marriages
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume contains marriage records of enslaved, freed (forro), and free individuals registered in the Church of  São João Batista (Baptista) de Niterói-RJ between 19 Jul 1754 and 24 Feb 1795 (the last legible date). It has no opening charter; the closing charter was signed in  Niterói on 25(?) Nov 1795 by Visitor Pizarro. Vicar João Bento Barros de Souza, Vicar Francisco da Silva Trancoso, Vicar José da Costa Lopes, and Coadjutor João Rebello de Mello Abreo signed the entries. In addition to marriage records, the volume documents pastoral visits on the following dates: 17 Oct 1758, 23 Nov 1767, 02 Apr 1770,  and 14 Mar 1787. The petitioners include Portuguese individuals and well as individuals abandoned (exposed) as children. In addition to the mother church, marriages were celebrated in the Chapel of  Santa Rosa, the Church of Nossa Senhora da Candelária in Rio de Janeiro (in which case the couple were natives of and baptized in the parish (freguesia) of São José, also in Rio de Janeiro. The following individuals appear as slave owners, among others: Doctor Antonio Tavares da Roza, Captain Domingos Nunes d'Ávila, Captain José Fernandes Souza, Captain Antonio Ferreira e Silva, and Sargeant João Dias Barboza. Captain José Pinto appears as the witness of a marriage between two enslaved individuals. African ethnonyms/"nations" mentioned:  Angola, Benguella, Congo, Guiné (Guinea), Mina e Rebollo.

coverage.institution: Catedral de São João Batista de Niterói

format: The volume consists of 142 numbered, sequential folios; however, the numbers are not always legible. The cover and binding were preserved, though many folios have holes or are torn or otherwise deteriorated due to components of the original ink. The records do not appear in chronological order. Due to their fragile condition, it was not possible to photograph the following folios: fl 10v - fl 14v; fl 27f - fl 40v; fl 66f- fl 70v; fl 83; fl 86; fl 102. Dimensions: 30cm x 21.5 cm.

subject: Marriages
Brazil
volumes.description: This volume contains marriage records of enslaved, freed (forro), and free individuals registered in the Church of  São João Batista (Baptista) de Niterói-RJ and dating from 17 Sept 1781 through 22 Dec 1827. The opening charter was signed in Niterói on 16 Sept 1781 by visitador (visitor) Joam (João) Pinto Roiz. The closing charter was signed in the same location and date by Francisco Manoel de Souza, who initialed the folios of the volume. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Vicar Francisco da Silva Trancoso, Vicar José da Fonseca Valente, Coadjutor João Rabello Mello de Abreo, Vicar José Joaquim d'Avila, Vicar Luis Manoel Martins de Sá. The volume records pastoral visits conducted on 20 Sept 1781, 28 Feb 1784, 14 Mar 1787, 20 May 1791, 23 Nov 1795, 20 Jul 1799, 25 Apr 1803, and 21 Jul 1812. The people whose marriages are documented in this volume include Portuguese individuals, individuals abandoned (expostos) as children in the Santa Casa de Misericórdia or in private homes; Ensign João Antonio Correa Botelho, Ensign Manoel Antonio Coelho, Lieutenant Francisco Ribeiro de Faria, Colonel Manoel da Silva (?), and Lieutenant Pedro da Silva Barros. The volume also includes a marriage record of a wedding between an English man and a Brazilian woman; as the two were adherents of different religions, they had to receive special authorization in order to marry (fl 127f). Freed people contracting marriage include a bride whose parents were slaves of Captain Felis (ou Felix) de Souza Castro. In addition to the mother church, the volume documents marriages celebrated in the Chapel of Nossa Senhora da Conceição de Pendotiba. African ethnonyms/"nations" mentioned: Angola, Benguela, Congo, Ganguela, Guiné (Guinea), Moçambique (Mozambique), and Rebollo.

coverage.institution: Catedral de São João Batista de Niterói

format: The volume is comprised of 144 numbered, sequential folios. The cover and binding have been preserved and there is evidence that the volume was previously restored using Japanese paper. However, some of the folios present a number of holes and other signs of damage due to ingredients used in the original ink.  Dimensions: 31cm x 22cm.

The opening charter was signed by Canon Luis Britto on 04 Jul 1884. Canon Vicar João Aureliano Correia dos Santos signed the closing charter on (?) Jul 1884; he initialed each folio as "J. Aureliano." The volume records the marriage of a Portuguese man with a freed (forra) woman (34F). The volume documents a pastoral visit realized on 06 Dec 1884 by Pedro, Bishop of São Sebastião do Rio de Janeiro. Canon Vicar João Aureliano Correia dos Santos and Father João Cordeiro da Cruz Saldanha signed all entries.

volumes.title: Book 3 of Free and Freed Marriages, 1829-1847
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Marriages
Brazil
volumes.description: This volume contains marriage records of freed (forro) and free individuals registered in the Church of São João Batista (Baptista) de Niterói-RJ dating from 11 Jan 1829 through 09 Jan 1847. The opening charter was signed by  J. Caetano Ferr.a de (?) [Ferreira de ?] on 06 May 1821. The closing charter was signed by Marcellino Fernandes Viera on 02 Jun 1821 and by interim scribe Silveira on 26 Aug 1835. Marcellino Ferreira initialed the folios. There are a number of references to Portuguese individuals. Among others, this volume records the marriages of: Lieutenant  Duarte Joaquim Jorge (3V), Lieutenant João de Moraes Madureira (7F), the daughter of the Squadron Chief (Chefe de Esquadra) Rodrigo Antonio Moraes de Lamare (15V), the daughter of Lieutenant Pedro Henrique da Cunha (27F), Lieutenant Antonio Joaquim de Oliveira (33V), Captain Ricardo Tompson (33V), the daughter of Lieutenant Captain Pedro Antonio Nunes (38F), Colonel Francisco Xavier Calmon da Silva (41F), the daughter of Lieutenant Colonel José Rebello Vasconcellos Souza Coelho Henriques (63F), and the daughter of Lieutenant Colonel Antonio Jozé Castriolo (80V). The following African ethnonyms and "nations" are mentioned: Mina, Cabinda, Casange, Benguela, Angola. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Vicar Joaquim de Sta Anna Lamego and Vicar Callado Thomas d'Aquino.

format: The volume is comprised of 131 numbered folios and a cover. Most of the folios are in good condition; some have been damaged by insects or ink. Dimensions:  33cmX21cm.

volumes.title: Book 4 of Freed and Free Marriages, 1857-1872
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Marriages
Brazil
volumes.description: This volume contains marriage records of freed (forro) and free individuals registered in the Church of São João Batista (Baptista) of Niterói-RJ dating from 12 Oct 1857 through 07 Feb 1872. The opening charter, dated 16 Apr 1844, was signed by Francisco Manoel de Bulhões, and there is no closing charter. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Vicars Thomaz de Aquino and Antonio de Mello Muniz Maia, commissioned Vicar Miguel Joaquim D’Araujo, Coadjutors José Luiz D'Almeida Martins and Antonio Gomes Xavier, and Canon Antonio da Immaculada Conceição. Included are marriages between Catholics and Protestants as well as free blacks. “Kidnapping” is mentioned in a free creole marriage on folio 92. Marriages recorded in the volume took place at the churches of N. Sra. das Dores (Ingá), N. Sra. da Conceição, and Ss. Sacramento na Corte  as well as the chapel of Asilo de Santa Leopoldina. The former name of the city of Niterói, the “Villa Real da Praia Grande,” is mentioned.

volumes.title: Book 5 of Freed and Free Marriages, 1872-1878
creator: British Library EAP1047

Brazil
volumes.description: This volume contains marriage records of freed (forro) and free individuals registered in the Church of São João Batista (Baptista) of Niterói-RJ. Entries date from 10 Feb 1872 through 27 Jul 1878. The opening and closing charters were signed by municipal judge Luis Mattoso Duque Estrada da Camara, who also initialed the folios. The opening charter is dated 02 Dec 1871, while the closing charter is undated. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Coadjutor Antonio Gomes Xavier and Vicar cônego Antonio da Irmandade da Conceição. Among the betrothed were individuals abandoned in the Santa Casa de Misericórdia as children; Portuguese, Paraguayan, French, Irish, and one Swedish and Swiss individual, respectively (whose religions were listed as Calvinist and Lutheran and which apparently did not impede their marriage to a Catholic bride). The following individuals, among others, appeared in the volume: Lieutenant João Gonçalves da Silva, Lieutenant Cândido de Araújo Vianna, Doctor Lino Cassiano Jardim, Dom Antonio Ignacio da Silveira, Doctor Augusto Cesar de Andrade Duque Estrada, Major José Claro Ferreira da Silva, Lieutenant Antonio Serafim Oliveira Mello, Ensign José Eulalio da Cunha Martins, Doctor José Martins Rocha, Ensign Francisco Luis Barrandon, Bacherel Antonio Joaquim Ribeiro Junior, Doctor Phelippe Sampaio Corrêa, Ensign Pedro de Alcantara Cezar Burlamarque, Doctor Luiz Henrique Pereira de Campos, Major João Netto da Silva, Doctor Francisco Cassiano Ferreira Alves, Doctor Joaquim Pedro Villaça Junior (the son of the appelate judge (desembargador) by the same name), Doctor Paulo Cezar de Andrade, Doctor Luiz Francisco da Veiga, Doctor Francisco de Paula Fraga, Doctor Luis Alves Leite de Oliveira Bello, Doctor Joaquim José de Souza Breves Junior (son of the commander by the same name), Doctor Joaquim Carlos Travassos, Doctor Antonio Azdano Gonçalves de Almeida, Doctor Francisco Pires de Carvalho Aragão, Doctor João da Costa Lima e Castro, Colonel Augusto Francisco Caldas, Doctor Antonio Francisco da Costa Ramos, Doctor Candido Drumond Furtado de Mendonça, Doctor André Theodoro Trufevesson, and Eduardo Eugenio Guimarães Backer, brother of Alfredo Augusto Guimarães Backer (president of Brazil between 1906 and 1910). Witnesses include the Baron of Lagoa and the Baron of Cotegipe.

volumes.description: This volume contains marriage records of free individuals registered in the Church of São João Batista (Baptista) de Niterói-RJ dating from  27 Jul 1878 through 24 Jul 1884. The opening and closing charters were signed by the Juiz da Provedoria, Luiz Pinto de Miranda. A second closing charter, signed by Cônego Antonio da Immaculada Conceição and dated 04 Jun 1878., is also included. Entries were signed by  Cônego Antonio da Immaculada Conceição. There is a record of a pastoral visit on  06 Dez 1884 by Bishop Pedro of São Sebastião do Rio de Janeiro. The volume records the marriages of individuals from diverse locales, including:: Cantagallo, Guimarães, Porto, Campos, Petrópolis, Maricá, Maranhão, and Rio Bonito.  Em muitos registros uma licença do "Juiz de orphãos" da cidade para a celebração do casamento. Nas folhas 09 consta o casamento do Primeiro Tenente da Armada Raymundo de Mello Furtado de Mendonça.

volumes.description: This volume contains baptismal records of enslaved individuals registered in the Church of São João Batista (Baptista) of Niterói (Nictheroy) and covers the period between 24 May 1855 and 14 April 1867. The opening and closing charters are dated 31 January 1855 and were signed by the Municipal Judge and Provedor of Capellas and Residências Luiz de Hollanda Cavalcanti de Albuq. (Albuquerque). They note that the volume contains 154 numbered folios. The entries were signed by the following priests: Coadjutor Francisco Manoel D'Almeida (?) Guimarães, Vicar Thomaz de Aquino, Vicar Antonio de Mello Muniz Maia, Miguel Joaquim D'Araújo, and Coadjutor José Luiz de Almeida Martins. The following clergy are listed as celebrants: Vicar Eduardo Andrade Lima, Guilherme Teixeira do Castro, and Vicar Leandro José Rangel de Sampaio. Relatively few African ethnonyms are mentioned; those that appear include: Congo, Nagô, Cassange, Angola, Mina, Monjolo.

volumes.description: This volume contains baptismal records of enslaved individuals registered in the Church of São João Batista (Baptista) of Niterói (Nictheroy) and covers the period between 21 April 1867 and 01 October 1883. The opening charter was signed in 1868 by Father Josias (?) do Nascimento Silva and states that the volume has 101 folios for recording the baptism of enslaved people. The registers were signed by the following priests: Vicar Antonio de Mello Muniz Maia; Coadjutor Antônio Gomes Xavier (who, after 17 March 1872, began to sign the registeries as Vicar); Vicar Antônio (?) Conceição; Vicar Cônego Luis Raymundo da Silva Britto; and Father Thomaz de Aguiar. The Lei Áurea ("Golden Law") which freed Brazilian slaves is reproduced at the conclusion of the volume. African ethnonyms mentioned: Angola.

Brazil
volumes.description: This volume contains baptismal records from the Church of São João Batista de Icaraí (Carahy, Carii, Carahi) of children born to enslaved mothers after the passage of the Free Womb Law. Entries date from 10 December 1871 to 18 March 1888. The opening and closing charters were signed by Antonio André Lima Costa. The volume consists of 198 numbered folios. On folio 120 there is a correction that refers to folio 119. The entries were signed by the following clergy: Vicar Antonio Gomes Zavier, Conego Antonio da Imaculada (Immda) Conceição, Luis Raymundo da Silva Britto, Vicar Manuel Correia de Figueiredo, and João Aureliano Correia dos Santos, who transcribed the "Golden Law" that ended slavery in Brazil that closes the volume. Following the transcription of the Golden Law, the remaining pages are blank.

volumes.description: This volume contains baptismal records of enslaved individuals registered in the Church of São João Batista (Baptista) de Villa Real da Praia Grande (the former name of the city of Niterói) and covers the period between 06 January 1828 and 25 February 1855. The opening charter is dated 06 October 1826 and was signed by José Caetano Perr.a (Pereira) de Aguiar; on the following folio there is a vow in the name of Father Joaquim de Santa Anna Lamego. The closing charter is dated 23 October 1826 and was signed by Father Francisco Manoel Almeida Guimarães. The volume consists of 296 numbered folios. The entries were signed by the aforementioned Father Lamego and by the following priests: Thomas de Aquino (after 14 November 1829) and Coadjutor Francisco Manoel D'Almeida Guimarães (after 01 November 1851). The following African ethnonyms and "nations" appear: Minna (Mina), Cabinda, Angolla (Angola), Congo, Moçambique (Mozambique), Monjolo, and Benguela.

volumes.description: This volume records burials of children born to enslaved mothers after the passage of the Free Womb Law and registered in the Church of São João Batista (Baptista) de Icaraí (Carahy, Carii, Carahi). Entries date from 06 May 1872 through 19 Oct 1887. Antonio Andre Lima signed the opening charters on 01 May 1872. Folios 75-198 are blank. The volume documents a pastoral visit conducted on 06 Dec 1884 by the Bishop of São Sebastião do Rio de Janeiro. The volume records, among others, the burials of children of enslaved women belonging to First Naval Lieutenant João Evangelista Bandeira Machado (2F), Commander Gabriel Pereira Lima (4V), Captain Joaquim Augusto de Narciza (6V), Lieutenant Candido José da Silva Bourbon (12F), Appellate Judge (Desembargador) Manoel José de Freitas Travassos (14F), First Naval Lieutenant Jozé Maria do Nascimento (15V), Appellate Judge (Desembargador) Antonio Francisco de Azevedo (22F, 27F, 43F, 58F), successors of Vicar Antonio de Mello Muniz Maia (22F), Major Francisco Xavier Baptista (32V), Captain Fermino José Correa (34V), Colonel Manoel Vidal Leite Ribeiro (36F), Lieutenant Captain Miguel de Souza Mello e Alvim (51V), Captain Camillo Luiz Gomes (53V), Appellate Judge (Desembargador) Joaquim Teixeira Peixoto de Abreu Lima (59F), Commander Raphael Ascoli (66V), Captain Ernerto Euzebio de Souza Mello (70V), Captain Dario Junto de Souza Mello (74F) and numerous doctors (5F, 13F, 18F, 19F, 28V, 30F, 31F, 33F, 35V, 36V, 37F, 40V, 43V, 45V, 46V, 47V, 49V, 51F, 51V, 52F, 54F, 60F, 60V, 64V, 72F). Entries were signed by the following clergy: Vicar Antonio Gomes Xavier, Vicar Conego Antonio da Imaculada (Imm.da) Conceição, Vicar M.el Corr.a Figueredo (Figr.do), Vicar Conego Luis Raymundo da Silva Britto, and Canon Vicar João Aureliano Correia dos Santos

volumes.title: Book 1 of Freed and Free Burials, 1727-1728, and Slave and Free Marriages, 1734-1754
creator: British Library EAP1047

Brazil
volumes.description: This volume contains burial records of freed (forro) and free individuals as well as marriages of enslaved and free individuals registered in the Church of  São João Batista (Baptista) de Icaraí (Carahy, Carii, Carahi), dating from 12 (?) 1727 through 09 May 1754. The volume lacks an opening or closing charter. Marriage records date from 8 Mar 1734 through 9 May 1754; burial records begin on folio 123 and cover the period between 12 (?) 1727 and 03 Jul 1728. Several freed black indivduals (pretos forros) appear as witnesses to marriages. The volume also documents the burial of Portuguese individuals. The volume documents pastoral visits on  27 Oct 1742 by D.os Mr.a, on 27 Aug 1747 by Vicar Gavião, and one on 27 Jun 1754. The volume includes testaments. African "nations"/ethnonyms mentioned: Guanguella; Benguella (Benguela); Congo; Angola; Guiné (Guinea). Entries were signed by the following clergy:  Vicar Joze da Costa Peixoto; Coadjutor Salvador Vieira (Vr.a) de Souza; Vicar An.to Fran.co Bento; Vicar Fernando (Fern.do) Machado (Mx.do) de Souza; Vicar Fran.co Esteves de Araujo; Commissioned Vicar Joze Caetano Ban.o Pr.a; Vicar João Bento Barros de Souza; Father João  Gomes da Silva (Sylva); and Coadjutor Hieronymo Barboza.

volumes.title: Book 10 of Freed and Free Burials, 1866-1872
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Burials
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume contains burial records of freed (forro) and free individuals registered in the Church of São João Batista (Baptista) de Icaraí (Carahy, Carii, Carahi) between 01 Jan 1866 and 14 Jul 1872. Francisco Xavier Baptista signed the opening and closing charters in Niterói on 02 Jan 1866 and initialed all folios. Vicar Antonio de Mello Munis Maia and Coadjutor/ Vicar Antonio Gomes Xavier signed all entries. Among others, the volume records the burials of children (inocentes), including freed children (forras), abandoned children (expostas), and white children; Major Antonio José Pinella; Lieutenant Colonel Antonio Martins; Antonio Leocádio, Division Chief; Manoel Nogueira Lacerda, First Lieutenant of the Imperial Navy Doctor João Joaquim Gouvêa; Doctor Eduardo Thompson, whose death was a suicide ("suffering from alienation, he was led to commit an act of desperation" ="soffrendo de alienação o obrigou a praticar aquelle acto de desespero", on fl19); Captain Francisco Antonio Pinto; Reverend Francisco de Moraes Loureiro; Baron of Carapebús; Doctor Luis Alvares de Andrade; Doctor Francisco Manoel Soares de Souza; Lieutenant Colonel José Maria da Costa Araujo; Colonel Lozimo Ferreira da Silva; Reverend José Antonio Teixeira Pimirim; Lieutenant Colonel José Ferreira da Silva; Doctor João José Pimentel; Ensign João Antonio Falleiros; Captain Benjamim Rodrigo Baptista; Doctor Antonio Francisco Leal; Capitão de Mar e Guerra José Maria Galhardo; Vicar Antonio de Mello Munis Maia; indivduals hailing from the provinces of Minas Gerais, São Paulo, Rio Grande do Sul, Santa Catarina, Sergipe, Piauí, Pernambuco, Paraíba, and Bahia; natives of Portugal,Spain, Italy, France, Germany, England, Russia, Paraguay, and Gibraltar; and freed Africans ascribed the following ethnonyms/"nations": Angola, Benguela (Benguella), Cabinda, Cassange, Congo, Mina, Moçambique (Mozambique), and Monjolo (Monjollo). Each entry recorded the burial ocation.  The burial of Paraguayan Manoel Seuni, a prisoner of war, is recorded on folios 116v and 117f; his burial was dated 28 Jan 1870 and may be related to the Paraguayan War (Dec 1864-Mar 1870). The burial of Benvinda, a freedwoman of mixed racial origins (parda liberta), is recorded on folio 153f; her mother was a slave of Vicar Antonio de Mello Munis Maia.

volumes.description: This volume contains burial records of freed (forro) and free individuals registered in the Church of São João Batista (Baptista) de Icaraí (Carahy, Carii, Carahi) between 17 Jul 1872 and 27 Dec 1874. The opening and closing charters were signed by João da Costa Lima e Castro, Judge of Law of the First Civil Court, on 11 Jul 1872. The volume records, among others, the burials of freed individuals with enslaved mothers; Portuguese and Italian individuals; First Naval Lieutenant  André de Paula Lima (4V); First Lieutenant Francisco Pereira do Valle (18V); Appellate Judge (Desembargador) Vicente Ferreira da Silva Bueno (42F); Captain Francisco Forquato de Souza Caldas (54F); Baron of São Gonçalo Belarmino Ricardo Siqueira (60V-61F); Frigate Captain Silvino José de Carvalho Rocha (52F); Luiz Hypolito de Azevedo Coutinho, Captain of the Police Corps (73F); Frigate Captain Jozé Antonio de Oliveira Bastos (74F); Baron of Araguary (Araguari) João Maria Wandenkolk (75V); First Naval Lieutenant João Evangelista Bandeira Machado (80V); and Baron of Saquarema José Pereira dos Santos (90F). African ethnonyms/"nations" mentioned: Cabinda, Mina, Angola. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Vicar Antonio Gomes Xavier and Canon Vicar Antonio da Imaculada (Imm.da) Conceição.

coverage.institution: Catedral de São João Batista de Niterói

volumes.title: Book 13 of Freed and Free Burials, 1874-1881
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Burials
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume contains burial records of freed (forro) and free individuals registered in the Church of São João Batista (Baptista) de Niterói (Nictheroy) between 30 Dec 1874 and 25 Jul 1881. It has no opening or closing charter; Canon Vicar Antonio da Immaculada Conceição signed each entry. The volume documents burials in the Cemetery of  São Francisco de Paula "na Côrte"; the Maruhy Cemetery; and the Cemetery of S. Francisco Xavier "na Côrte". Among others, the volume contains burial records of free Africans (africanos livres); Portuguese, German, and Italian individuals; sharecroppers ("agregados"); individuals abandoned in the Santa Casa de Misericórdia and deceased in the Hospital de São João Batista; and soldiers and sargeants of the "Police Corps of this City." African ethnonyms/"nations" mentioned: Mina. Folios 108 and 17, respectively, document the burials of Brigadiers Joaquim Rodrigues Coelho Helby and Pedro Pinto de Araujo Corrêa.

volumes.title: Book 15 of Freed and Free Burials, 1885-1889
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Burials
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume contains burial records of freed (forro) and free individuals registered in the Church of São João Batista (Baptista) de Icaraí (Carahy, Carii, Carahi) between 12 Aug 1885 and 09 Jan 1889. Vicar General Luis Brito signed the opening charter in Rio de Janeiro on 07 Jul 1884, while Canon Vicar João Aureliano Correia dos Santos signed the closing charter and initialed the folios in Niterói on 15 Dec 1884. Canon Vicar João Aureliano Correia dos Santos also signed each entry. Among others, the volume documents the burials of Portuguese individuals; children (inocentes), some of whose parents remained enslaved; and prominent local citizens, including Counselor Manoel José de Freitas Travassos; Doctor Celestino Gomes de Oliveira; Doctor Antonio Martins Torres; Major Jeronymo Pinto Netto dos Reis; Doctor José de Sá Carvalho; Counselor Affonso Arthur de Almeida e Albuquerque; Doctor Antonio Francisco Villaça; and Doctor Augusto Manoel Pralon. Each entry includes information about the cause of death (when known) and place of burial.

volumes.title: Book 6 of Free and Freed Burials, 1795-1854
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Burials
Brazil
volumes.description: This volume records burials  of free whites and freed people of color (pretos forros) registered in the Church of São João Batista (Baptista) de Icaraí (Carahy, Carii, Carahi). Entries date from 25 June 1795 to 24 January 1854. The opening charter was signed by Vicar José de Souza Azevedo Pizarro de Araujo and dated 14 November 1795; the priest noted that a book of burial records follows. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Vicar Joze Joaquim D'Avila, Vicar Joaquim de Santa Anna Lamego, Vicar Thomas de Aquino, and Coadjutor Francisco Manoel D'Almeida Guimarães. Some of the burial records of freed people of color note that their spouse was still enslaved. African nations and ethnonyms mentioned: Angola, Benguela.

volumes.title: Book 8 of Freed and Free Burials, 1854-1862
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Burials
Brazil
volumes.description: This volume contains burial records of freed (forro) and free individuals registered in the Church of São João Batista (Baptista) de Niterói between 20 May 1854 and 06 Oct 1864. Interim Municipal Judge Sabino Francisco Frougeth signed the opening and closing charters on 09 Jan 1854; he also initialed the folios. The volume opens on folio 6. Due to their poor condition, it was not possible to photograph folios 6-11, 40-43, or 53-66 . Vicar Antonio de Mello Muniz Maia noted that on the authorization of the Bishop of the Chapel, he signed all entries left by his predecessor, Vicar Thomaz de Aquino. The volume includes some burials of free Africans (africanos livres), as well as of Portuguese, English, Spanish, and Italian individuals, among others. Burials of two unidentified men are documented on folios 32F and 48V. The burial of the free son of an enslaved woman appears on folio 139F.  Among the burials documented in this volume were those of Brigadier Antonio Rodrigues Gabriel de Castro (17V), daughters of  Lieutenant Colonel Augusto Francisco Caldas (18F e 18V), Lieutenant Colonel Manoel Alves d'Andrade (19V), the tutelada of Lieutenant Francisco de Virgem (25F), Captain Cipriano Francisco da Matta (36V), the servent of Major Ricardo Thompson (46V), the wife of Capitão de mar e guerra Pedro da Cunha (48F), the wife of  Captain Manoel Fortunato de Moraes (49F), the son of the Division Chief Jesuino Lamego Costa (79F), the son of Capitão Mor Gabriel Alves Carneiro (84F), children of Captain Francisco Joaquim Barcellar (90F e 111F), Brigadier José da Costa Azevedo (104V), the daughter of Captain José Ignácio Coimbra (110V), Lieutenant Captain Joaquim José do Sacramento (111F), Lieutenant Colonel Libornio Jose de Almeida (122V), Lieutenant Colonel Manoel Rodrigues de Moura (131F), Lieutenant of the Police Corps (tenente do corpo policial) Manoel José Mendes de Lima (162F), Doctors (69V, 103V e 162V), and soldiers of the Police Corps (soldados do corpo policial) (80V e 143F). The following African "nations"/ethnonyms appear in the volume: Benguela, Mina, Moçambique (Mozambique), Culubur (Calabar?), Congo, Rebola, Guiné (Guinea), Cabinda, and Angola. The following clergy signed the entries: Coadjutor Francisco Manoel d'Alm.da Guim.es, Vicar Thomaz de Aquino, Vicar Antonio de Mello Muniz Maia, Commissioned Vicar Miguel Joaquim de Araújo, Pro Parocho Father José Joaquim da Silva, Coadjutor José Luiz d'Alm.da Martins

volumes.title: Book 9 of Freed and Free Burials, 1862-1865
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Burials
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume contains burial records of freed (forro) and free individuals registered in the Church of São João Batista (Baptista) de Niterói (Nictheroy) between 07 Oct 1862 and 29 Dec 1865. It has no opening charter; Augusto Francisco Calvaro signed the closing charter on 30 Oct 1862. Vicar Antonio de Mello Muniz Mai signed all entries. Among others, the volume records the burials of Captain José Joaquim Gonçalves de Siqueira (folio 1) and Ensign José Geraldo Gomes; soldiers of the "Police corps of this city" and the "Batallion of Volunteers for the Country"'; natives (naturais) of  Bahia, Minas, Porto Alegre, Campos, Macaé, Paraty; Portugal; and France; sharecroppers (agregados); and liberated Africans ("africanos livres"). African ethnonyms/"nations" mentioned: Quiçaman (Kisama?), Benguela e Cabinda. The majority of decedents were interred in the Maruhy Cemetary (Cemitéro do Maruhy).

volumes.title: Book 2 of Free Baptisms, 1872-1888
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Baptisms
Brazil
volumes.description: This volume contains baptismal records of children born to enslaved mothers after the passage of Law  2040/1871, the "Free Womb" Law (Lei do Ventre Livre) and registered in the church of Nossa Senhora da Conceição de Jurujuba, Niterói, Rio de Janeiro. The entries date from 14 Jan 1872 through 04 Apr 1888. The opening and closing charters were signed by the Secretary of the Government of the Province of Rio de Janeiro, Joaquim Mattoso Duque Estrada Camara, on 01 May 1872. Priest Venancio Lins Telles Barreto signed the records. On folio 29v, the "Golden Law" ("Lei Áurea") that ended slavery in Brazil dated 04 Nov 1890 is transcribed and signed by Canon João Aureliano Correia dos Santos. Following this, the remaining folios in the volume are blank.

coverage.institution: Nossa Senhora da Conceição de Jurujuba

format: The volume consists of 198 numbered folios. It has a cover; some of the folios have been damaged by ink and insects. Dimensions: 32cm X 22cm.

volumes.title: Book 1 of Free Baptisms, 1861-1883
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Baptisms
Brazil
volumes.description: Book of baptisms of slave, free, and freed (forros/libertos) individuals from the church of Nossa Senhora Conceição de Jurujuba, Niterói, Rio de Janeiro dating from 22 Feb 1861 through 20 May 1883. The opening charter was signed by  Municipal Judge José Sebastião Ferreira da Silva on 09 Oct 1861. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Vicar Celestino Otero, João de Araujo Alves Mariano, and Venancio Lins Telles Barreto. There are records of children born to enslaved mothers after the passage of the Free Womb Law (Lei do Ventre Livre). Color and social condition of the baptized individuals are recorded underneath the name. There are some records of "manumissions in the baptismal font" (alforrias na pia batismal) as well as of baptisms of adults born in Africa.

creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Burials
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume contains burial records of children born to enslaved mothers after the passage of the Free Womb Law (Lei do Ventre Livre) and free individuals registered in the Church of  Nossa Senhora da Conceição de Jurujuba, Niterói, Rio de Janeiro. Entries date from 11 Mar 1872 through 08 Sep 1887. The opening and closing charters were signed by the Secretary of the Government of the Province of Rio de Janeiro, Joaquim Mattoso Duque Estrada Camara, on 01 May 1872. Priest Venancio Lins Telles Barreto signed the entries. In some instances, the cause of death is recorded. At the end of the volume, the Golden Law ending slavery in Brazil is reproduced and signed by  Cônego João Aureliano Correia dos Santos in 1890. After folio 13, the remaining folios are blank.

volumes.title: Book 10 of Free Burials and Baptisms, 1821-1854
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Baptisms
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume records burial and baptismal records of free individuals registered in the Church of São Sebastião de Itaipu, Niterói-RJ. The burial records date from  28 Dec 1821 through 02 Mar 1852, while the baptismal records date from 12 May 1822 through 05 Mar 1854. The volume has no opening charter; the closing charter was signed by Manoel Roiz Gomes and dated 24 Jan 1822. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Vicar Antonio Brandão de Mello; Vicar Demetrio João Vieira Falcom; Brother Manoel de Sta. [Santa] Viridiana; Vicar João Baptista Lopes; and Vicar José Brithualdo de Mello. The volume also includes some testaments. Several of the registered record the names of grandparents and the recognition of paternity. On folios 125 and 126v, there are petitions for the registry of baptisms of freed individuals in the book of free people.  Baptisms were recorded on folios 8 through 149v, while burials were recorded on folios 150 through 195.

volumes.title: Book 7 of Slave, Freed, and Free Burials, 1762-1766
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Burials
Brazil
volumes.description: This volume records the burials of enslaved, freed (forro), and free individuals registered in the Church of  São Sebastião de Itaipu, Niterói-RJ. Entries date from 12 May 1762 through 01 Jan 1766; it has no opening or closing charter. Several testaments mention slaves, property, and emancipations. There are some burials of abandoned individuals ("expostos"). African nations/ethnonyms mentioned: Guiné (Guinea), Angola. The volume documents a pastoral visit realized on 23 Mar 1765 by Vicar Barros. All entries were signed by Manoel Francisco da Costa.

volumes.title: Book 11 of Freed and Free Burials, 1870-1892
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Burials
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume records burials of freed (forro/liberto) and free individuals registered in the Church of São Sebastião de Itaipu, Niterói-RJ.Burial records date from   05 Nov 1870 through 19 Dec 1892, with the exception of one burial dated 23 Apr 1931. The opening and closing charters were dated posterioraly and were both signed on 27 Nov 1938 by Vicar Father Francisco Arlotti, who also initialed the folios. All entries were signed by Vicar José de Castro e Silva. Entries document the burial  of children (inocentes), individuals abandoned in the  Santa Casa de Misericórdia, some of which included an identification number, and a French individual. The cause of death was frequently recorded. Enterments took place in the cemetery of the  Matriz of São Sebastião de Itaipu and, in some cases, in the cemetery of the Chapel of Nossa Senhora da Conceição, identified as an affiliate parish. Among the burial records is an entry concerning a "preta livre" (free black woman) aggregated to one Captain João Machado Nunes. African "nations" and ethnonyms mentioned: Moçambique (Mozambique), Cassange (Kasanze), Benguella (Benguela), Congo, Angola, and Rebollo (Rebolo).

coverage.institution: São Sebastião de Itaipu

volumes.title: Book 1 of Slave and Free Baptisms, 1742 - 1744
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Baptisms
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume records baptisms of enslaved and free people from the parish (Freguesia) of Paraíba dating from 29 Jun 1742 through 15 Jul 1744.  A majority of the baptized were enslaved Africans and their descendants, although free people of color, indigenous people, and, to a lesser extent, Europeans also appear. A number of African ethnicities and place designations, such as Benguela, Cabo Verde, Ganguella, Grujanga, Mongolo, Mina, and Massangano are recorded. There are references to freed (forro) godparents. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Antonio del Aguda, Luiz de Soveral Coelho, and Agostinho de Barros Lima.

coverage.institution: Freguesia de Paraíba

format: The volume is incomplete and consists of 4 insect-damaged folios. It does not have a cover. Dimensions: 29cm x 21cm.

volumes.title: Book 1 of Slave and Free Burials, 1729-1752
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Burials
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume contains burial records of enslaved and free people from the parish of Paraíba dating from 27 March 1729 through 10 January 1752. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Manoel Vianna, Francisco Azevedo, Francisco Barreto de Neves, and Luiz de Soveral Coelho. African ethnonyms mentioned: Benguela and Angola. Burial locations mentioned include the cemetery of the Igreja de Nossa Senhora da Conceição e São Pedro e São Paulo da Parahyba, the Capella da Parahibuna, the Capella de Nossa Senhora do Bom Serrat (Monte Serrat?). In some entries, the cause of death was recorded. There is no opening charter; the closing charter is dated 28 Dec 1757.

volumes.description: The volume records slave burials registered in the Church of Nossa Senhora da Conceição de Rio Bonito. Entries date from 10 Dec 1799 through 08 Aug 1815, although they do not appear in chronological order--the volume opens on folio 72, with an entry dated 09 Aug 1807. The volume does not have an opening or closing charter. There is a record of a pastoral visit by Vicar Barboza on  26 Oct 1813. The following African ethnonyms appear: Angola.The following clergy signed the entries: Vicar Jozé de Almeida Lima, Coadjutor Antonio Luis de Oliveira Cortes, Vicar Joaquim (Joaq.m) Pereira (P.ra) dos Reis, and Coadjutor Alvaro Evangelista.

volumes.title: Book 6 of Slave Baptisms, 1828 - 1842
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Baptisms
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume records slave baptisms registered in the Church of Nossa Senhora da Conceição de Rio Bonito, Rio Bonito-RJ. The opening charter is dated 19 Jun 1826 and was signed by Manoel (?) Araujo; the closing charter and date are illegible and were signed by André Victorino de Oliveira. The entries date from 20 Feb 1828 to 19 Dec(?) 1842. The following priests signed the entries: Vig. Antonio Maria Ribas Sandim; Vig. Interino Manoel Machado da Motta; Vig. Tito Pereira de Carvalho; Vig. Encomendado Bernardo Antonio Lima de Velasco. On folio 232v, there is a register of a "donation" of an enslaved girl to the niece of her original owner in the baptismal act. Slaves owned by the following individuals appear: Captain Vicente José Gomes; Alferes Ignacio Henriquez de Souza; Captain José de Castro Cardozo; Major Ignacio Rangel de Marins Carilho; Captain Manoel Antonio Ferreira; Lieutenant Francisco de Paula Pereira.

volumes.title: Book 1 of Freed and Free Marriages, 1829-1843
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Marriages
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume records marriages of freed (forro) and free individuals registered in the Church of Nossa Senhora da Conceição de Rio Bonito between 08 Dec 1829 and 19 Dec 1843. The opening charter was signed on 29 Oct 1829 by Canon Vicar General Narcizo (?), while Manoel Machado da Motta signed the closing charter on 14 Nov 1829, por Manoel Machado da Motta. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Vicar Manoel Joaquim Catarino, Father José Ramos de Carvalho, Vicar Tito Pereira de Carvalho, and Commissioned Vicar Bernardo Antonio Lima de Velasco. The volume documents marriages of Portuguese individuals; weddings celebrated in the oratory of the fazenda (agricultural property) of Capitão Mor Francisco Marinho Machado; an enslaved bride owned by one Ensign Joaquim Vicente de Velasco (fl 28f); as well as the marriages of Lieutenant Egas Munis da Silva, Lieutenant Colonel Joaquim Antão (?) Andrade, and Lieutenant Francisco Manoel de Araújo.

coverage.institution: Nossa Senhora da Conceição do Rio Bonito

format: The volume consists of 144 numbered, sequential folios with no cover. The majority of the folios are bound together; some present signs of insect damage. Folio 27 is missing.

volumes.title: Book 3 of Freed and Free Marriages, 1844-1867
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Marriages
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume records marriages of freed (forro) and free individuals registered in the Church of Nossa Senhora da Conceição de Rio Bonito. Entries date from 26 Jan 1844 through 14 Sep 1867. The opening and closing charters were signed by Francisco Xavier Cavalcanti Albuquerque on 08 Nov 1851. The following clergy signed the entries:Vicar Tito Pereira de Carvalho, Commissioned Vicar Manoel João Catarino, and Vicar Virtulino Bezerra Cavalcante. The betrothed parties include Portuguese individuals; freed people (forros) whose parents remained enslaved; freed people who were formerly slaves of Major Ignacio Rangel de Marins Couto, Lieutenant Vicente José Marinho, and Lieutenant João Pedroza Braga; and a freed woman who was "freed at the baptismal font" (liberta de pia), on fl 95f.  The marriages recorded in this volume were celebrated in a number of locations, including the oratory of the fazenda do Tanguá, the chapel of Rio Seco, and the Chapel of Santa Anna, a parish affilitated with the mother church of Nossa Senhora da Conceição de Rio Bonito.

coverage.institution: Nossa Senhora da Conceição do Rio Bonito

format: The volume is comprised of 241 numbered, sequential folios without a cover. The folios have partially come loose from the binding; the volume has been damged by insects and the original ink used. Dimensions: 31cm x 21cm.

volumes.title: Book 4 of Freed and Free Marriages, 1867-1876
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Marriages
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume records marriages of freed and free people registered in the Church of  Nossa Senhora da Conceição de Rio Bonito between 05 Oct 1867 and 09 Feb 1876. Luiz Manoel Mendes Vellozo signed the opening and closing charters on 30 Sept 1867 and initialed each folio. The opening charter was also signed by Judge  Joaquim Victorino Pereira Alves on 10 Feb 1876. Among the betrothed were freed people whose parents remained enslaved; captains and lieutenants appear as witnesses to a number of marriages. The volume documents a pastoral visit realized on 3 Jun 1898 by Francisco, Bishop of Petrópolis and one conducted by D. Carlos Alberto Navarro, Bishop of Niterói, on 02 Jul 1997 (the Chancellor of the Archbishopric, Father Edson Assunção, also signed this record). Among the marriages recorded in this volume are those of the son of Major Justino José de Miranda to the daughter of Captain Antonio Maria da Silva Castro (9F); the son of Captain Gabriel Moreira Damasco (12V), the daughter of Lieutenant Felicissimo José da S.a Ribeiro (17F), the daughter of Captain Antonio Maria da Silva Castro (24F), the son of Lieutenatn José da Silva Cardoso (35V), the daughter of Captain Antonio Joaquim Sundré Coelho (65V), and the son of Captain Luiz Antonio do Nascimento (150F). Vicar Virtulino Bezerra Cavalcanti signed each entry.

coverage.institution: Nossa Senhora da Conceição do Rio Bonito

format: The volume consists of 154 numbered, insect-damaged folios that have come loose from the cover. Dimensions:  31.5cm X 21.5cm.

volumes.title: Book 6 of Freed and Free Marriages, 1883-1890
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Marriages
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume records marriages of freed (forro) and free people registered in the Church of Nossa Senhora da Conceição de Rio Bonito between 24 Nov 1883 and 24 Oct 1890. Municipal Judge Domingos Lopes Estrela signed the opening and closing charters on 10 Jan 1883 and initialed each folio in the volume. The volume records marriages of free individuals with enslaved parents; emancipated Africans (africanos livres); marriages for which enslaved people served as witnesses; ex-slaves freed by the Golden Law (Lei Áurea) that ended Brazilian slavery (Imperial Law no. 3.353). General Vicar Monsenhor Brito appears numerous times throughout the volume. The volume also records a pastoral visit by Francisco, Bishop of Petropolis, on 05 June 1898 and one by D. Carlos Alberto Navarro, Archbishop of Niterói, on 02 Jul 1997. Father Edson Assunção also signed this record. Vicar Virtulino Bezerra Cavalcanti signed all entries.

coverage.institution: Nossa Senhora da Conceição do Rio Bonito

volumes.title: Book 2 of Freed and Free Burials, 1804-1830
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Burials
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume contains burial records and some testaments of freed (forro) and free indivduals registered in the Church of Nossa Senhora da Conceição de Rio Bonito. Entries date from 15 Jun 1804 through 03 Apr 1830. The opening and closing charters are not included; the volume opens on folio 5. Não constam os termos de abertura e encerramento. O livro se inicia na folha 5. The folios were initialed by one Macedo. 24 folios have not been identified. The following folios are missing: 1-4, 26, 32, 34, 37, 39-51, 80, 82, 107-110, 113, 137, 145, 146, 148, 153, 155, 164-167. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Vicar  Jozé de Almeida Lima, Coadjutor Antonio Luis de Oliveira Fontes, Coadjutor Francisco Roza de (?), Vicar Joaquim (Joaq.m) Pereira (Pr.a) dos Reis, Coadjutor Alvaro Evangelista, Coadjutor Alvaro Pereira (Pr.a) dos Reis, Coadjutor Joze da Trindade Cardozo Ribeiro, Vicar Antonio (An.to) Maria (M.a) Ribas Sandim, Coadjutor Andre Victorino de Oliv.a, Vigário Fr.co Braz S.to Roza, Pro Parocho Joze Ramos de Carvalho, and Pro Parocho M.el Machado da Motta.

volumes.title: Book 5 of Freed and Free Burials, 1867-1879
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Burials
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume records burials of freed (free) and free individuals registered in the Church of Nossa Senhora da Conceição de Rio Bonito and dating between 01 Aug 1867 and 16 Jul 1879. The opening and closing charters were signed by one Mesquita (Mesq.ta) on 30 Oct 1866, who also enumerated the pages. Some burials of white (Portuguese) indivdiuals are also recorded in the volume. The volume records the burials of Major Manoel Joaquim da Costa (35V), Tenente Manoel Gonçalves Ferreira do Nascimento (94V), Lieutenant João Diego Duarte (199V), Captain João Duarte Loureiro (122F), Father Alexandre Rodrigues Braga (?) de Gaviões (137V), Lieutenant José Soares de Resende (179V), Captain Manuel Per.a dos Santos Silva (198V), and Father Antonio José de Freitas (199F). African ethnonyms and "nations" mentioned: Benguella (Benguela), Congo. Vicar Virtulino Bezerra Cavalcanti signed the entries.

coverage.institution: Nossa Senhora da Conceição do Rio Bonito

format: The volume consists of 199 loose numbered folios and a cover. Dimensions: 39cm x 26cm.

volumes.title: Book 7 of Freed and Free Burials, 1879-1885
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Burials
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume contains burial records of freed (Forro) and free individuals registered in the Church of Nossa Senhora da Conceição de Rio Bonito and dating from 16 Jul 1879 through 8 Dec 1885. The opening and closing charters were signed by  João José de Andrade Bastos in Rio B on 11 Jul 1879 in Rio Bonito; he also enumerated the folios of the volume. All entries were signed by Vicar Virtulino Bezerra Cavalcante. The volume records burials of children (inocentes), abandoned children (expostos), Portuguese individuals, and one French person. Africans whose "nation"/ethnonym is recorded as Congo, Kasanze (Cassange), and Cabinda are among the free people of color whose burials are recorded in the volume. Among the freed people whose burial is recorded are: a freed woman (forra) aggregated to the Rio Seco plantation (fazenda) of Commandor Camillo de Souza Couto; a freed woman (forra) whose mother was a slave of Colonel Carlos  José Marinho; and a "freed black woman" ("preta liberta") who was a slave of the descendants of Captain Manoel Pereira dos Santos Silva. The following free burials, among others, are included in the volume: Ensign (Alferes) Francisco de Assis Moreira; Ensign José Alves Campos, Father Bernardo Antonio Lima de Velasco; Captain Francisco de Paula Corrêa de Sá; Captain Alexandre Pereira de Mendonça; Lieutenant José da Costa Marcello; Doctor José Antonio de Mattos e Silva; and Captain Quirino José da Fonseca.

coverage.institution: Nossa Senhora da Conceição do Rio Bonito

The entries record whether the enslaved was a "domestic/house worker" ("serviço da casa/doméstico") or agricultural worker ("serviço da roça/rural"); in some entries, the word "property" is used instead of "slave." There is a record of an emancipation at the baptismal font (alforria de pia) on folio 169f. A pastoral visit by Francisco, Bishop of Petrópolis, was recorded on 19 Jun 1898. The following clergy signed the entries: Raphael Teixr.a (Teixeira) de Az.do (Azevedo) M.do (Machado), Manoel Joaquim Henrique de Azevedo Farias, Raphael Capobianco, Rufino José Alvares, and Jacintho Messias Peixoto.

volumes.title: Book 2 of Slave, Freed, Indian, and Free Baptisms, 1804-1826
creator: British Library EAP1047
subject: Baptisms
Brazil
volumes.description: The volume records baptisms of slaves, freed (forro/liberto), indigenous (índios ) and free people registered in the Church of Nossa Senhora de Nazaré,  Saquarema-RJ. Entries date from 25 Jul 1804 through 26 Dec 1826. The volume does not include opening or closing charters. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Vicar Miguel Gomes Torres; Commissioned Vicar Antonio Gomes Dias; Interim Vicar João Ignacio de Santa Roza; Vicar José de Santanna Costa; Vicar José Pinto Pinheiro; Father José Victorino de Souza. Among the individuals who appear in the volume are natives (naturais) of Rio Bonito; Maricá; Itaboraí; Santo Antonio de Sá; Campos dos Goytacazes; and Ilha do Pico. Some of the baptisms took place in private chapels located on plantations, such as that of Captain João da Silva Ribeiro; some of the baptisms were performed by chaplains like José Francisco de Carvalho. The volume also records baptisms of children of freed (liberto/forro) individuals and numerous manumissions at the baptismal font ("alforrias de pia.") A pastoral visit on 02 Aug 1812 by Visitor Barboza is included in the volume. Numerous entries record the names of the baptized child's grandparents. African "nations" and ethnonyms mentioned: Angola and Benguela.

volumes.description: The volume records burials of freed (forro) and free individuals registered in the Church of Nossa Senhora de Nazaré, Saquarema-RJ and dating from 13 Apr 1829 through 10 Mar 1836. The opening charter was signed in Rio de Janeiro on 30 Dec 1829 by J. Caetano Ferreira de Aguiar, while the closing charter was signed in Rio de Janeiro on 10 Jan 1827 by Joaquim de Souza Maia, who also numbered and initialed the folios. Entries were signed by the following clergy: Vicar José Pinto Pinheiro, Coadjutor José de Santa Anna Costa e Oliveira, and Commissioned Vicar Antonio Joaquim de Freitas. In addition to the burial records, numerous testaments of free people recorded in the volume document the transfer of slaves to their descendants and, in some cases, the manumission of the enslaved indivdual after the owner's death. African "nations" and ethnonyms mentioned: Rebola, Cabinda, and Angola. A number of entries record the burial of children (inocentes) and several record the burials of Portuguese natives. Among others, the burials of the following indivdiuals are recorded: Major Adeadato José Victorino, Father Antonio Ribeiro, Vicar José Pinto Pinheiro (one of the signatories of the volume) and Captain Manoel de Jesus Maria. A few burials of enslaved individuals were recorded in the volume; there is no notation that they were also recorded elsewhere, such as the burials of Thereza, slave of Captain Jeronimo Francisco de Oliveira, and of Vicente, slave of Manoel Francisco da Costa. Burial entries concerning freed children (inocentes) note the status of the child's parents; in the case that one parent was still enslaved, the owner was identified.
